column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.3
#T_SP=de.tudarmstadt.ukp.dkpro.core.api.ner.type.NamedEntity|identifier|value

#Text=# Sparse-Depth-Completion  This repo contains the implementation of our paper \[Sparse and Noisy LiDAR Completion with RGB Guidance and Uncertainty\](https://arxiv.org/abs/1902.05356) by \[Wouter Van Gansbeke\](https://github.com/wvangansbeke), Davy Neven, Bert De Brabandere and Luc Van Gool.

#Text=If you find this interesting or relevant to your work, consider citing:  ``` @inproceedings{wvangansbeke\_depth\_2019,     author={Van Gansbeke, Wouter and Neven, Davy and De Brabandere, Bert and Van Gool, Luc},     booktitle={2019 16th International Conference on Machine Vision Applications (MVA)},     title={Sparse and Noisy LiDAR Completion with RGB Guidance and Uncertainty},     year={2019},     pages={1-6},     organization={IEEE} } ```  ## License  This software is released under a creative commons license which allows for personal and research use only.
#Text=For a commercial license please contact the authors.

#Text=You can view a license summary \[here\](http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc/4.0/)  ## Introduction Monocular depth prediction methods fail to generate absolute and precise depth maps and stereoscopic approaches are still significantly outperformed by LiDAR based approaches.
#Text=The goal of the depth completion task is to generate dense depth predictions from sparse and irregular point clouds.
#Text=This project makes use of uncertainty to combine multiple sensor data in order to generate accurate depth predictions.
#Text=Mapped lidar points together with RGB images (monocular) are used in this framework.
#Text=This method holds the \*\*1st place\*\* entry on the \[KITTI depth completion benchmark\](http://www.cvlibs.net/datasets/kitti/eval\_depth.php?
#Text=benchmark=depth\_completion) at the time of submission of the paper.
#Text=The contribution of this paper is threefold: \* Global and local information are combined in order to accurately complete and correct the sparse and noisy LiDAR input.
#Text=Monocular RGB images are used for the guidance of this depth completion task. \* Confidence maps are learned for the global branch and the local branch in an unsupervised manner.
#Text=The predicted depth maps are weighted by their respective confidence map.
#Text=This is the late fusion technique used in our framework. \* This method ranks first on the KITTI depth completion benchmark without using additional data or postprocessing.
#Text=See full demo on \[YouTube\](https://www.youtube.com/watch?
#Text=v=Kr0W7io5rHw&feature=youtu.be).
#Text=The predictions of our model for the KITTI test set can be downloaded \[here\](https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1U7dvH4sC85KRVuV19fRpaMzJjE-m3D9x).  !

#Text=\[demo\](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9694230/51806092-db766c00-2275-11e9-8de0-888bed0fc9e8.gif)   ## Requirements Python 3.7 The most important packages are pytorch, torchvision, numpy, pillow and matplotlib.
#Text=(Works with Pytorch 1.1)   ## Dataset The \[Kitti dataset\](www.cvlibs.net/datasets/kitti/) has been used.
#Text=First download the dataset of the depth completion.
#Text=Secondly, you'll need to unzip and download the camera images from kitti.
#Text=I used the file `download\_raw\_files.sh`, but this is at your own risk.
#Text=Make sure you understand it, otherwise don't use it.
#Text=If you want to keep it safe, go to kitti's website.

#Text=The complete dataset consists of 85898 training samples, 6852 validation samples, 1000 selected validation samples and 1000 test samples.  ## Preprocessing This step is optional, but allows you to transform the images to jpgs and to downsample the original lidar frames.
#Text=This will create a new dataset in $dest.

#Text=You can find the required preprocessing in: `Datasets/Kitti\_loader.py`  Run:  `source Shell/preprocess $datapath $dest $num\_samples`  (Firstly, I transformed the png's to jpg - images to save place.
#Text=Secondly, two directories are built i.e. one for training and one for validation.

#Text=See `Datasets/Kitti\_loader.py`)  Dataset structure should look like this: ``` \|--depth selection \|-- Depth      \|-- train            \|--date                \|--sequence1                \| ...
#Text=\|--validation \|--RGB     \|--train          \|--date              \|--sequence1              \| ...

#Text=\|--validation ```   ## Run Code To run the code:  `python main.py --data\_path /path/to/data/ --lr\_policy plateau`  Flags: - Set flag "input\_type" to rgb or depth. - Set flag "pretrained" to true or false to use a model pretrained on Cityscapes for the global branch. - See `python main.py --help` for more information.
#Text=or   `source Shell/train.sh $datapath`  checkout more details in the bash file.  ## Trained models Our network architecture is based on \[ERFNet\](https://github.com/Eromera/erfnet\_pytorch).
#Text=You can find the model pretrained on Cityscapes \[here\](https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1U7dvH4sC85KRVuV19fRpaMzJjE-m3D9x?
#Text=usp=sharing).
#Text=This model is used for the global network.
#Text=You can find a fully trained model and its corresponding predictions for the KITTI test set \[here\](https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1U7dvH4sC85KRVuV19fRpaMzJjE-m3D9x?
#Text=usp=sharing).
#Text=The RMSE is around 802 mm on the selected validation set for this model as reported in the paper.
#Text=To test it:  Save the model in a folder in the `Saved` directory.

#Text=and execute the following command:  `source Test/test.sh /path/to/directory\_with\_saved\_model/ $num\_samples /path/to/dataset/ /path/to/directory\_with\_ground\_truth\_for\_selected\_validation\_files/`  (You might have to recompile the C files for testing, provided by KITTI, if your architecture is different from mine)  ## Results  Comparision with state-of-the-art:  !

#Text=\[results\](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9694230/59205060-49c32780-8ba2-11e9-8a87-34d8c3f99756.PNG)   ## Discussion  Practical discussion:  - I recently increased the stability of the training process and I also made the convergence faster by adding some skip connections between the global and local networks.

#Text=Initially I only used guidance by multiplication with an attention map (=probability), but found out that it is less robust and that differences between a focal MSE and vanilla MSE loss function were now negligible.
#Text=Be aware that this change will alter the appearance of the confidence maps since fusion happens at mutliple stages now
#Text=.
#Text=- Feel free to experiment with different architectures for the global or local network.

#Text=It is easy to add new architectures to `Models/\_\_init\_\_.py`  - I used a Tesla V100 GPU for evaluation.  ## Acknowledgement This work was supported by Toyota, and was carried out at the TRACE Lab at KU Leuven (Toyota Research on Automated Cars in Europe - Leuven)
